Award.AwardTitle: In Situ Imaging and Analysis of Solid Oxide Fuel Cell Anodes during Degradation

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1134052 PI Chiu

The principal objective of this study is to develop in situ imaging techniques that allow the direct observation of solid oxide fuel cell (SOFC) anodes under operational conditions and provide a scientific and engineering understanding of degradation in SOFC anodes. Meeting this objective will help enhance SOFC long term performance and reliability and enable SOFCs as a viable technology for efficient and sustainable energy conversion. High resolution in situ x-ray imaging using a newly developed transmission x-ray microscope (TXM) will be used to achieve this goal. The PI will use hard x-ray nanotomography developed by him at the Argonne National Laboratory Advanced Photon Source (APS) to nondestructively obtain high resolution (32 nm) 3-D images of an operating SOFC anode. The PI will develop in situ x-ray imaging and spectroscopy techniques to observe anode degradation during operation and perform detailed microstructural analysis to understand degradation mechanisms in SOFC anodes. Aged SOFC anodes will be provided by the Ecole Polytechnique Federale de Lausanne (EPFL). Preliminary results obtained from ex situ nondestructive 3-D imaging of SOFC anodes indicate Ni-phase particle coarsening is significantly affected by operational time. This project will build on the preliminary results to elucidate fundamental knowledge regarding the mechanisms and pathways that cause degradation. This project will involve two graduate students and will have outreach activities for undergraduate and high school students.
Intellectual merit includes a detailed understanding of SOFC anode degradation due to Ni coarsening during operation and its effect on performance. Knowledge obtained from this study will be used to elucidate degradation mechanisms, especially the role of different coarsening mechanisms (Ostwald ripening, particle migration, and evaporation), the corresponding operating conditions in which they occur, and how and where such mechanisms originate in the microstructure. The research team assembled for this study works extensively in the area of SOFCs including x-ray imaging of SOFC materials, detailed charge-transfer modeling and testing, thermal stress, and material characterization.
Broader impacts of this study include external collaborations that will explore new sustainable energy technologies for our society. EPFL will provide SOFC samples, perform experiments, and provide data for model validation. APS will provide synchrotron facilities to image SOFC electrode samples using a 32 nm resolution hard x-ray microscope system. In terms of education, the PI will work closely with the UConn Engineering Diversity Program to identify several top high school students, especially from underrepresented groups, from over 25 local area high schools for a summer internship in the PI's lab. The PI and his students will engage in on-site research at EPFL and APS.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF funded researchers at the University of Connecticut in Storrs, Connecticut, in collaboration with colleagues at synchrotron sources have developed in situ, x-ray microscopy methods for 3D imaging and 3D spectroscopy of solid oxide fuel cell material at the nanoscale. These methods are capable of distinguishing chemical bonding states in complex 3D microstructures at 30 nm resolution in situ. This approach is an extension of two existing transmission x-ray microscopy methods, the first of which, x-ray nanotomography, was previously developed by the Principal Investigator and collaborators. The second method, 3D x-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) spectroscopy, complements the morphological information from the first by nondestructively mapping in 3D the elemental composition and chemical bonding states of microstructural components in energy material samples. Both techniques use a transmission x-ray microscope (TXM). X-ray nanotomography involves collecting a series of x- ray transmission images as the sample is rotated and irradiated by a monochromatic incident x-ray beam from a synchrotron source. This project has also created the data analysis algorithms and software needed to interpret the images to better understand the role of 3-D microstructure and morphology on performance.

The methods developed provides a means of directly observing and quantatively analyzing the 3-D microstructure and chemical composition of energy materials at the nanoscale and in situ. The more detailed knowledge gained from these measurements will assist scientists and engineers in better understanding the performance and reliability of batteries, fuel cells, and other energy storage and conversion devices. This understanding can then, in the future, be potentially used for the rational design of such materials.

Depending on the energy of the incident x-ray beam, the materials examined will exhibit different x-ray absorption characteristics. XANES spectroscopy allows the researchers to select x-ray energy settings where the materials will show the most distinct absorption behavior. These energy levels are called “energy levels of interest.” X-ray nanotomography scans are taken at the energy levels of interest and the data is processed to yield a digital representation and quantitative performance measures. The microstructure and composition of this digital representation can then be characterized and analyzed to obtain scientific insights about battery and fuel cell operation. These results reported by this project demonstrate that the approaches created by this project can discern both microstructural features and material chemical composition in three dimensions at the nanoscale.

The microstructure of materials used in solid oxide fuel cells can be reconstructed using XANES nanotomography but the microstructure is dynamic and evolves over time. The oxidation of nickel in these electrodes can affect the morphology and decrease cell performance. The transmission x-ray microscope allows for the structural changes to be imaged in situ. Electrodes are complex microstructures with multiple phases so to demonstrate the capabilities of this instrument; oxidation of nickel powder has been performed. Nickel powder spheres are placed on the tip of an alumina pin and placed in a controlled gas and temperature environment where the reaction can be studied. Changes in the absorptivity and path length can be monitored and correlated back to reaction rates by using a shrinking core model. Agreement was observed between the experimental results and the numerical model at different operating temperatures. Solid oxide fuel cell anodes were also studied to determine how the morphology evolves during operation. With the creation and application of analytical and numerical analysis tools, the 3-D microstructure can be correlated to performance.
